Dear Mrs. Fernandez:
Attached is the Special Investigation Report for the above referenced facility. Due to the
violations identified in the report, a written corrective action plan is required. The
corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must include the
following:
 How compliance with each rule will be achieved.
 Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
violation.
 Specific time frames for each violation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
 For repeat violations, identify why the previous CAP was unsuccessful.
 How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
 The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you desire technical assistance in addressing these issues, please feel free to contact
me. In any event, the corrective action plan is due within 15 days. Failure to submit an
acceptable corrective action plan will result in disciplinary action.
Please note that violations of any licensing rules are also violations of the MISEP and
your contract.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the local office at (866) 685-0006.

ALLEGATION:
Youth's mental health medication needs are not being met due to a lack of medical
professional on duty. Youth has not been able to get new glasses.
INVESTIGATION:
This complaint was received and investigated jointly with the DHHS Specialist. The
complaint reported additional concerns that are not within the purview of DCWL and
were not investigated and thus, not reported on in this report. The initial complaint
noted the following, “Youth A (16) is currently in placement at Methodist Children's
home Services. Youth A has not taken any of his mental health medications
because there are no nurses or medical staff on duty. Youth A needs new glasses,
however because there is no medical staff on duty, he is unable to obtain new
glasses.”
I interviewed Director 1 at the facility, on 11/18/21, jointly with the DHHS Specialist.
Director 1 is the Director of Residential Services. Director 1 said that if a youth had
broken glasses, they would tell the Nurse. However, Director 1 reported that the
former nurse left the facility a couple of weeks prior, and they are in process of hiring
a replacement. In the interim, Director 1 said that Director 2 is covering some of the
duties that were coordinated by the nurse, such as making appointments and
ensuring medications are ordered. During this time, Director 1 said that youth can
tell staff of any needs and the staff are to report the needs to their supervisor, who
would then notify Director 2.
I interviewed Youth A’s Therapist on 11/18/21, jointly with the DHHS Specialist. The
Therapist reported having worked with Youth A for about one month and noted that
individual sessions occur weekly. The Therapist said that Youth A declined two
sessions due to not feeling well (one stomachache and one headache) so she did a
brief check in with Youth A instead of a full session. The Therapist said that Youth A
had not reported any broken glasses to her or that he was not getting his
medication. The Therapist reported no concerns.
I interviewed Director 2 at the facility, on 11/18/21, jointly with the DHHS Specialist.
Director 2 is the Director of Children’s Services. Director 2 denied knowing that
Youth A’s glasses were broken and noted that if she had known, she would have
made an appointment for them to be repaired or replaced. Director 2 stated she has
seen Youth A three to four times over the last week or two and he had not
mentioned his glasses breaking and had not mentioned that he was not getting
medication. Director 2 said that she has been checking on medication weekly for any
youth with concerns and checks medications monthly for youth with no concerns.
Director 2 said that she started overseeing the medication and medical components
when the former nurse resigned. This was reported to have started right before
Halloween. Director 2 said that she is familiar with the requirements of what needs to
be done, as she used to supervise the nursing staff prior to some organizational
restructuring in July. When asked about the three open entries on Youth A’s
medication administration record, Director 2 said that there should not be open
3

entries. Director 2 did not know why the option of “physically unable to take” was
selected on the forms.
I interviewed Youth A at the facility, on 11/18/21, jointly with the DHHS Specialist.
We met with Youth A right after he returned from school. Youth A reported that he
accidentally broke his glasses on Monday, 11/15/21, the same day that his worker
came to visit. Youth A said he dropped them after school. Youth A said that he told
his worker and told Staff 1 (he thinks) on the same day or the next day. Youth A said
that no one had come to talk to him about the glasses yet. Youth A said that he had
not told anyone else, including Director 2 or his Therapist, even though he had seen
them. Youth A further reported that he has not been given one of his morning
medications, and thought it was medication Z. Youth A reported how he is doing well
in the program and was recently seen for a medication review where they lowered
some medication dosages, including medication Z being lowered 20mg. Youth A
said that no one told him why he was not getting medication Z, and he had not
received it for about the last week and a half. Youth A said he always takes his
medication and does not refuse, except if he does not need something like his nasal
spray or inhaler. Youth A’s medication logs were reviewed with him, with emphasis
on medication Z. It was observed that medication Z had previously been
administered at 20mg twice a day and it changed to 20mg once daily. Youth A
reported that he didn’t realize that the lowered dose resulted in him not receiving one
of the pills and he thought he was not being given the medication. Youth A reported
that this now made sense to him.
I met with Director 1 again on 12/06/21. Director 1 said that she checked with staff
and found that they had not entered medication counts into the computer system,
which caused an error when staff tried to document that they gave medications. It
forced an error code to have to be entered and one of the options is “physically
unable to take.” Director 1 said that the staff opted for this entry to be able to move
forward in the system and continue passing medications. Director 1 said that when
medications are delivered, the staff are to enter the new counts in the computer
system. It was reported that third shift usually does this and the supervisor on third
shift is the secondary counter. Reportedly, some staff said that this has been an
issue since the nurse left, while others said it was longer than that. The Director said
that the medications were being given but documented this way due to the error
code required. On 12/21/21, Director 1 reported that Youth A’s glasses had been
sent in for repair but were not back yet.
I met with Staff 1 and Staff 2 (separately), on 12/08/21, jointly with the DHHS
Specialist. Both staff were asked about the entries of “physically unable to take” that
they entered on some of Youth A’s medication administration logs. Both staff
provided congruent accounts as noted by Director 1. Due to staff not logging in the
number of new medication when received, an error was triggered in the computer
system and forced the staff to choose a code from a drop-down list. Both staff said
that they had administered the medication but chose that code so that the computer
system would allow them to move on to the next item. Both staff said that they could
4

not go back and fix the counts. Both staff also noted that they documented this in the
daily log.
Documentation reviewed as part of this investigation:
 Youth A’s medication administration records for the months of September,
October, and November 2021 were reviewed on 11/18/21.
o Medication Z was observed to have changed from 20mg twice daily to
20mg once daily on October 26, 2021. All documentation for
administration of medication Z was present.
o The November form was observed to have missing documentation for
administration (blank entries) on the 13th, 14th, and 16th, for
medication C.
 Facility’s medication administration policy
APPLICABLE RULE
R 400.4142 Health services; policies and procedures.
(1) An institution shall establish and follow written health
service policies and procedures addressing all of the
following:
(a) Routine and emergency medical, and dental, and
behavioral health care.
(e) Dispensing medication.
ANALYSIS: There is no evidence to support the allegations that Youth A
was not provided routine medical care related to the
repair/replacement of his glasses. The glasses broke on the day
the complaint was made and Youth A had not even reported to
the facility that they were broken, which allowed no time for
them to know or act on the information. Additionally, through
review of Youth A’s medication administration records and his
own report on changes to his medications, it was found that he
was receiving his medication, but that the dosage of one
medication changed, which resulted in one pill rather than two.
This was just a misunderstanding by Youth A.
The facility did violate the rule, however, as during the review of
the medication administration records, it was observed that staff
did not document administering medication C on November 13th,
14th, or 16th, as those entries were left blank.
5

TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE:
It was additionally found that the staff were not always following
the proper methods for recording medication in the computer
system, which forced an error code for dispensing medication
even when the youth had received the medication. The staff
dispensing medications then had to select an error code
(physically unable to take) to continue in the system, rather than
being able to choose the correct option of having passed the
medication. By all accounts, the youth received the medication,
however, the facility must increase supervision of this process
while they hire another nurse to ensure that medications are
being administered and documented correctly. The
administration must also stress to staff that if there are errors
occurring, to notify the supervisor.
CONCLUSION: REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
